ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: lab skills working with a variety of model organisms

I gained a lot of applicable wet lab skills such as pipetting, gel electrophoresis, pcr, petri dish preparation, and more. Additionally, I gained insight on what its like to work with a wide variety of model organisms including drosophila, C. elegans, zebra fish, and more. I also greatly developed my scientific writing skills through the lab reports we had to write.

Writing concise lab reports (introduction, results, discussion), note-taking in a lab notebook, formatting of lab reports and lab notebook entries, handling of laboratory instruments (especially the spectrophotometer, dissecting microscope, and compound microscope), handling of model organisms (including fruit flies, c. elegans, zebrafish, and acinetobacteria bacteria).
I learned a lot about principles in a wet lab and experimental design

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed this course, and I don't think there are any aspects I would change

Strengths: Very well organized and structured class. Dr. Moreno's lab manual handouts were very well written and always gave me a comprehensive understanding of what we'd be doing in lab that day as well as its real world implications and importance. The class was also fairly structured with having only 4 lab reports throughout the semester. While each lab report took upwards of 10 hours, we had about 2 weeks to do each one, so Dr. Moreno was understanding of our time. Dr. Moreno also chose experiments that were very engaging and relevant to a lot of current research going on so I felt like almost everything I did and learned in lab could be useful for any personal research I will go no to conduct outside of lab. 
Weakness: Lab days were usually very long with most days lasting at least 3 hours, so I feel like to be more efficient with time there could have been slightly less pre-lab lecture. However, they were useful.

Strengths: organization of week-to-week activities, clear expectations for writing the lab reports.
Weaknesses: lack of clear guidance on using the Prism software and of the figures required for the lab reports.
The course was very helpful in providing experimental design skills and key skills in scientific writing

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I really enjoyed my experience in the class
I would recommend this course to any student who is interest in doing on-campus biological research. It truly gave me a deep foundation of wet lab skills.

Yes! It may feel overwhelming at the start of the semester, but students were able to quickly adjust to weekly readings and assignments. This class is manageable so long as students establish a routine from the start.
Yes, for students interested in biology in practice and premeds this is a good course
